string-array.item: Be sure the soil is well-fertilized and healthy before planting your plants.
If planting seeds, be sure not to smother the seeds by covering them with too much soil.
You can ensure young plants will grow by adding water-solubile fertilizers to your watering can or hose sprayer.
Be sure that your plants are not competing with weeds for sunlight or other resources.
Some plants, like tomatoes, require stakes and support for their stems as they grow bigger.
Make sure to move your plants to larger containers if they grow too big.
Ensure your plant is receiving the adequate amount of light for its particular species.
Plants tend to need less water during nonactive growing seasons like winter.
Houseplants can be harmed by dry heater air in the winter. Be sure the air around your plants is humid enough so they can thrive.
Don\'t fertilize a plant that is dry. Water it first, then fertilize a few days later.
It is generally not recommended to re-pot your plants during the winter.
If growing houseplants, make sure the temperature of your home is within the acceptable range for your plants.
Alternating periods of drought and flood can really stress a plant\’s root system. Most plants like having their roots consistently moist, but not wet. Consult your plant\'s watering requirements.
When a houseplant gets attacked by an insect pest, the problem can quickly spread to other plants. Preventing insects from entering your home is key to indoor insect control.
It is also a good idea to wash the leaves of your plants several times a year. Dust and grime on houseplants doesn\'t just look bad; it is also bad for the health of the plant.
Never use a feather duster to clean plants, because dusters can easily transfer tiny insects or eggs from one plant to another.
Wash smooth-leaved houseplants with a moist, soft cloth and some insecticidal soap.
All plants need food, water and sunlight to survive, but different plants require different amounts of each. Consult individual plant requirements to determine what works best for your plant.
Good drainage is essential to healthy houseplants. Start with a good, organic potting soil (not regular soil) that has been mixed specifically for indoor gardening.
A 2–3 inch (5–7.5cm) layer of good mulch will help plants retain moisture, regulate soil temperature, and keep down weed pressure.

To remove the salt deposits that form on clay pots, combine equal parts white vinegar, rubbing alcohol and water in a spray bottle. Apply the mixture to the pot and scrub with a plastic brush. Let the pot dry before you plant anything in it.
Little clay pots make great cloches for protecting young plants from sudden, overnight frosts and freezes.
Got aphids? You can control them with a strong blast of water from the hose or with insecticidal soap.
Use leftover tea and coffee grounds to acidify the soil of acid-loving plants such as azaleas, rhododendrons, camellias, gardenias and even blueberries.
Use chamomile tea to control damping-off fungus, which often attacks young seedlings quite suddenly.
Companion planting is an excellent way to improve your garden. Some plants replenish nutrients lost by another one, and some combinations effectively keep pests away.
Compost needs time to integrate and stabilize in the soil. Apply two to three weeks prior to planting.
Like vining vegetables, but don’t have the room? Train your melons, squash, and cucumbers onto a vertical trellis or fence.
Keep dirt off lettuce and cabbage leaves when growing by spreading a 1-2 inch layer of mulch (untreated by pesticides or fertilizers) around each plant.
Insects can’t stand plants such as garlic, onions, chives and chrysanthemums. Grow these plants around the garden to help repel insects.
Healthy soil means healthy plants that are better able to resist pests and disease, reducing the need for harmful pesticides.
